properties.media:imagetext:
-2-
schedule this will be our only day in Istanbul.
Iwo days later
We made the rounds of Istanbul including the famous mosque
of St.
Sophia.
Hebe knew all about it from her
college training and
of course it was a great day for her.
It is the third largest church
in
the world -
outranked
only by St. Peters
in Rome and St. Pauls
in London.
Near
St. Sophia is the smaller but I think more beautiful
Blue Mosque which has six minarets instead of the conventional four
because of a mistake in the specifications.
We also took in the ex-
Sultan's palace
and saw there the finest collection of Chinese porcelain
in the world.
Chinese celadons by the hundreds, each one of which in
itself would be prized by most museums.
It seems that many of the old
Sultans ordered lots of china for their extensive kitchens and stored
it in
the
"cellar".
The next Sultan ordered more quite unaware of the
stock already on hand.
(Governments have a way of doing that!)
In
the reconstruction of the ancient kitchens great numbers of cases of
this porcelain were unearthed and formed this magnificent collection
consisting of pieces from the 14th Century through the 18th.
We drove around Istanbul and out toward Roberts College
along
the shore of the Bosphorus.
We had lunch at a famous plage
in the heart of the old city called Pandilla.
It is reached
on foot
up a narrow,
dirty alley.
Cabinet Ministers and leading businessmen
tread the alley to get the best food in the Middle East.
The owner,
Pandilla,
is a show in himself, standing behind a
slightly elevated
counter directing the whole operation, greeting his customers as they
come and go, shouting orders through a small window to the kitchen
and directing his weiters around
the small dining room.
Not a detail
missed his watchful check - the while he sipped brandy and became
more and
more mellow as the hour advanced.
He gets up at 4:00 a.m.
and goes
to
the market where he buys the best of everything.
He has
turned down hundreds of offers to open a better restaurant in Is-
tanbul as well as offers from New York, Paris,
etc.
He says that
he is doing all
right where he is and why move!
During
the day the snow turned into a snowstorm and then
a blizzard.
Our
plane was late starting from Brussels but we went
out to the airport at 2:00 a.m.
The plane came in at 3:00 a.m. and
was serviced in a
real blizzard, but eventually we were loaded on
board after Debby and Hebe had returned the werm clothes which we
had borrowed.
We taxied out tor the take-off and then taxied back
because number one engine - that's the one on the left - wouldn't
run
properly.
They struggled with it for a while and then postponed
the
flight for repairs and crew rest.
We were taken in a
bus to a
small hotel near the field and there we stayed all day while the
blizzard continued.
Debby and Hebe bundled up in blankets off the
airplane.
However, at 7:00 p.m.
we did get away and had an un-
eventful flight, back to Damascus and on to here - Delhi - where we
arrived at noon local time on Friday the 13th.
Tomorrow, Saturday, we are going to drive over to Agra
about a four hour trip, to see the Taj Mahal, stay in Agra overnight
and return
Sunday night.
